document_title: Effects of Simulated Microgravity on the Proteome and Secretome of the Polyextremotolerant Black Fungus Knufia chersonesos
summary_full: This study investigated the proteomic and secretomic responses of the black fungus Knufia chersonesos (wild type and a melanin-deficient mutant) to simulated microgravity (LSSMG) using high-aspect-ratio vessels. Proteomic analysis revealed differential expression of proteins involved in carbohydrate and lipid metabolism, transport, and ribosome biogenesis. Notably, no significant activation of stress components or starvation response was detected, except for scytalone dehydratase, which showed opposite regulation in the wild type and mutant. While morphological changes and survivability were not significantly affected by LSSMG, differences in protein modulation were observed between the wild type and mutant strains, suggesting that cell-wall melanization may influence the metabolic response to microgravity. This research provides insights into the adaptability of black fungi to space conditions and has implications for astrobiology.
key_findings: Simulated microgravity (LSSMG) altered protein expression in both the mycelia and secretome of Knufia chersonesos.
Proteins involved in carbohydrate and lipid metabolism, transport, and ribosome biogenesis were differentially expressed under LSSMG.
No significant activation of stress response or starvation pathways was observed, except for scytalone dehydratase, which was upregulated in the wild type and downregulated in the mutant.
Differences in protein modulation were observed between the wild-type (melanized) and mutant (non-melanized) strains, suggesting a role for melanization in microgravity adaptation.
LSSMG did not cause major morphological alterations or negatively affect the survivability of the fungal strains.
This study is the first to characterize the proteomic and secretomic response of black fungi to simulated microgravity.

conclusions: Knufia chersonesos exhibits a notable ability to cope with simulated microgravity conditions, with distinct proteomic and secretomic responses observed between the wild-type and melanin-deficient mutant strains. The absence of significant stress activation suggests an energy-saving strategy, while the observed protein modulations indicate potential adaptations in metabolism and transport. Cell-wall melanization appears to play a role in modulating the fungal response to microgravity, highlighting its importance for astrobiological applications.
impact_statement: This study reveals the adaptive capabilities of black fungi to microgravity, crucial for understanding their potential role in space exploration and planetary protection.
